item.title: Popularity determines how Chinese netizens select a political book rather than political alignment
item.description: Political Polarization in China? Political polarization is one of the most heatedly discussed issues in America. A great number of research papers delve into the topic. Recently, I have been exploring large-scale political books data derived from an online reading community. The data is composed of usersâ€™ book collections (When a user takes an interest in a book, she/he tags it). When I was probing into the data, one question struck me: is there political polarization in China?

item.title: The Geometry of Culture: How Chinese perceive and apprehend politics
item.description: Recently, I crawled data from a website and successfully obtained approximately 290,000 Chinese book summaries. I employed a neural-network word embedding model to discover the culture dimensions hidden under the large-scale book summaries. The idea was inspired by the paper The Geometry of Culture: Analyzing Meaning through Word Embeddings, which corroborated the effectiveness of the new methodological tool word embedding by constructing different cultural dimensions.
